eral government. But, typically, those constitutional questions that reach the
courts are not clear-cut. Even more so than statutes, provisions in the Con-
stitution are very general and sometimes vague. This vagueness serves a
purpose:  The  framers  of  the  Constitution  recognized  that  they  could  not
foresee every eventuality, so they wanted to allow future courts to interpret
the Constitution as cases arose. But the vagueness of the Constitution also
